data.title: A sea of red and white proudly on display at Canada Day celebrations at Canada Place
data.meta_description: The event kicked off with government officials welcoming 30 newcomers to the country through a citizenship ceremony.
data.text:
Article content

Amid a sea of red and white worn for celebrations at Vancouver’s Canada Place on Saturday, Aleen Sparrow stood out in a bright orange T-shirt that read Every Child Matters.

The 36-year-old weaver was asked by the host Vancouver Port Authority to represent Musqueam First Nations at the largest Canada Day celebration this year outside of the country’s capital.

Article content

The event kicked off with government officials welcoming 30 newcomers to the country through a citizenship ceremony.

Thousands of people headed downtown to take in the live music, dance performances and other free activities offered at the event, which was rebranded last year to be called Canada Together, with a returning theme of “weaving together the fabric of a nation.”

For many, it was a festival celebrating a country that has afforded them political freedoms.

Burnaby’s Leslie Newcombe, 64, came with her 24-year-old son in red clothing, face paint and a maple leaf necklace to ring in the occasion.

“We live in such a peaceful country, compared to many others. I’m celebrating that freedom today.”

Helen Nguyen, who migrated to Canada from Vietnam, said the event was an opportunity to celebrate a country that has provided her with new opportunity.

“I feel very thankful to call myself a Canadian and today is the best day to celebrate the peace I have here.”

But Sparrow told Postmedia News she struggled with the idea of showcasing her woven work at a Canada Day event.

Article content

“I was worried what it might mean if I was to be seen here, but as I was setting up I decided, you know what — I’m going to use this opportunity to show people that our culture is resilient and still being practised.”

She exhibited an intricately designed blanket that she, her mother and son wove out of sheep’s fur with a wooden loom.

“This form of weaving was lost for around 100 years due to residential schools,” Sparrow said. “My mother brought it back to our community 40 years ago after studying blanket-making” among other Indigenous women.

Her teenage son, Isaiah, wore the finished product to his high school graduation.

“He was so proud to walk across the stage wearing a blanket we made that connected him to his ancestors and graduating from a system and school that wasn’t meant for us,” Sparrow said.

In May 2021 the suspected unmarked graves of 215 Indigenous children were discovered on the grounds of a former B.C. residential school. Since then, Sparrow says the Canadian public has shown more respect and interest in Indigenous culture.

“People here are really trying to learn,” she said.

Advertisement 4

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

Another cultural practice lost during the residential school era was canoe carving and racing, said Ray Natraoro of the Squamish Nation.

The seventh-generation carver was proud to show off his latest red cedar in progress at Saturday’s event. The 21-foot-long canoe is just 40 hours away from being race ready.

“I’m here to tell people that First Nations people are still here and thriving, and to show that even though there is a big city around us, Indigenous people are living within the general population.”

For Port Coquitlam’s Amy Yue, who came to Saturday’s event so her children could participate in free activities, celebrating the holiday has become less appealing lately.

“I’ve had a hard time celebrating Canada Day since the discovery of those unmarked graves,” said Yue, who migrated to Canada from China with her parents when she was a child.

“Before I used to be so proud to be a Canadian, but I’m glad that they have changed the event to incorporate more Indigenous culture.”

sgrochowski@postmedia.com
